text: you know i have patients who i mean our patients are always going to disclose to us what they use we ask this question point blank which recreational drugs do you use and um a number of them will say hey you know two or three times a year i use cocaine and and they want to know what i think and again the goal in that situation is not to come across as preachy and dogmatic but it's to sort of have a point of view and have it be grounded and my point of view with cocaine has always been i don't think it's worth the risk and i don't think it's the right kind of drug because you know just as much as we're now talking about a framework for drugs i have a much simpler framework for drugs which is it's really only got two levers one is what is the physical risk of this drug to me as an individual so with cocaine what is the true risk of cardiac toxicity what is the risk of deepening physiologic dependence over time etc and then the second component to my framework is is this a drug that only alters your state or does it have the potential to alter a trait i'm borrowing that from the book called altered traits which which gets into this distinction and and so the idea being is you know psilocybin for anybody who's ever taken it is clearly a drug that alters your state but if it just altered your state you probably wouldn't take it because it's really not that pleasurable but the real benefit of is is the potential to alter a trait whether it be depression smoking cessation or something else and so if a drug can only alter your state but it has no potential to really alter your traits i.e how you behave off the drug is it worth it and and so my
title: Peter Attia's Framework for Recreational Drugs
